title: A 36-month, Multi-centre, Randomized, Double Blind, Placebo-controlled Study to Evaluate the Safety and Efficacy of Low Dose Ladostigil in Patients With Mild Cognitive Impairment (MCI)
description_brief: The purpose of this study is to determine whether treatment with the investigational drug ladostigil will delay the onset of Alzheimer's disease(AD) in patients with Mild Cognitive Impairment (MCI). MCI is now recognized as a precursor to AD and clinical tools are available to assess cognitive performance at this earlier stage. Ladostigil is currently under investigation for the treatment of AD. In this study, the investigators will be examining ladostigil at a lower dose level. At this dose level, ladostigil has been shown to reduce signs of early memory loss in animals. Thus, in this study the investigators are attempting to determine if earlier invention with a lower dose of ladostigil will significantly reduce initial memory loss and delay the subsequent progression to more serious cognitive dysfunction.
description_detailed: Ladostigil shows neuroprotective activity, reducing oxidative stress, activating microglia, and inhibiting pro-inflammatory cytokines in pre-clinical models. Study assessed its safety and potential efficacy in a 3-year, randomised, double-blind, placebo-controlled, phase 2 clinical trial in patients with mild cognitive impairment (MCI). Patients from 16 centers in Austria, Germany and Israel with MCI (Albert et al 2011), Clinical Dementia Rating (CDR) = 0.5, Mini-Mental State Examination (MMSE) \> 24, Wechsler Memory Scale - Revised Verbal Paired Associates ≤ 18, and medial temporal lobe atrophy were stratified by APOE4 genotype and randomly assigned (1:1 allocation) using blocks of 4, to receive either ladostigil, 10 mg per day, or placebo as identically-appearing capsules. The primary endpoint was onset of Alzheimer's disease (AD). Secondary endpoints were the NTB, DAD, and GDS. Exploratory outcomes were MRI-derived whole brain, hippocampus, and entorhinal cortex volumes; the NeuroTrax Mindstreams computerized cognitive battery; and the CDR. Between February 17, 2012 and August 1, 2013, we randomly allocated 210 patients to placebo (107 patients) or ladostigil (103 patients); 4 patients in each group lacked post baseline assessments. After 36 months 20.4% (21 of 103 patients) of the placebo group and 14.1% (14 of 99 patients) of the ladostigil group progressed to AD (log-rank test p=.16). There were no significant effects on NTB, DAD, or GDS outcomes. There was less decline in whole brain volume in the ladostigil group as compared to placebo (p\<.02), but not hippocampus and entorhinal cortex volumes, and CDR and a trend for less decline on the RAVLT total delayed score component of the NTB (p=.09). Fourteen patients taking placebo and 21 taking ladostigil discontinued treatment because of adverse events. Serious adverse events were reported by 26 (25.2%) patients in the ladostigil group and 28 (26.2%) patients in the placebo group. Ladostigil appeared safe, well-tolerated, and may have potential for improving memory and delaying progression to dementia.

outcomeMeasures.title: Conversion From Mild Cognitive Impairment to Alzheimer's Disease Compared to Placebo
outcomeMeasures.description:
Total number of conversions from Mild Cognitive Impairment to Alzheimer's disease across entire 3 year study period. Conversion is determined, or defined, by a Clinical Dementia Rating (CDR) score of greater than or equal to one.

Composite rating ranges from 0 no symptoms of dementia to 3 Severe symptoms of dementia.
outcomeMeasures.populationDescription: All randomized subjects with at least one post-baseline visit.

outcomeMeasures.title: Change in Geriatric Depression Scale for Ladostigil Versus Placebo Population
outcomeMeasures.description: Mean value change (from baseline) in Geriatric Depression Scale (GDS) across entire study period. The GDS ranges from 0 to 30. Scores of 0-9 are considered "normal", 10-19 "mildly depressed", and 20-30 "severely depressed".
outcomeMeasures.unitOfMeasure: Change from basline on units on a scale

outcomeMeasures.title: Change in Neuropsychiatric Test Battery for Ladostigil Versus Placebo Population
outcomeMeasures.description: Mean value change (from baseline) in Neuropsychiatric Test Battery (NTB) across entire study period. The NTB included the following well known cognitive tests: Rey Auditory Verbal Learning Test (RAVLT), Controlled Word Association Test (COWAT), Category Fluency Test (CFT), WMS-R Digit Span, and Trail Making Part A and B. The mean value was comprised of the z score of each of these tests with all z scores in the direction of higher scores better functioning. Range -3 to +3.
outcomeMeasures.populationDescription: Modified Intent to treat (all randomized subject with at least one post baseline assessment)
outcomeMeasures.unitOfMeasure: Change from basline on units on a scale

outcomeMeasures.title: Change in Disability Assessment in Dementia for Ladostigil Versus Placebo Population
outcomeMeasures.description: Mean value change (from baseline) in Disability Assessment in Dementia (DAD) across entire study period. DAD evaluates the basic and instrumental activities in daily activities of elderly people with dementia. Higher scores reflect better functioning. DAD ranges from 0 to 100.

drug: ladostigil (TV-3326) — oral small-molecule dual cholinesterase and brain-selective monoamine oxidase inhibitor; low dose tested (e.g., 10 mg/day in the cited 36‑month trial)
explanation_target: Reason: The trial description tests ladostigil to delay progression from MCI to Alzheimer disease, i.e., an intervention intended to modify disease course by neuroprotective/anti-atrophy effects rather than solely treating behavioral symptoms. The available literature describes ladostigil as an orally active small molecule with dual cholinesterase and brain‑selective monoamine oxidase (MAO‑A/B) inhibitory activity and additional neuroprotective/anti‑inflammatory effects, indicating a disease‑targeting pharmacologic approach rather than a biologic (monoclonal antibody/vaccine). citeturn0search2turn0search1

Act: Key extracted details from the trial and literature — drug: ladostigil (TV‑3326); trial design: 36‑month, randomized, double‑blind, placebo‑controlled in MCI; tested low dose (10 mg/day in the published phase 2 study). The published phase 2 trial evaluating low‑dose ladostigil in MCI explicitly assessed onset of Alzheimer disease as a primary outcome, consistent with a disease‑modifying intent. citeturn0search0turn0search1

Reflect: Given the drug is a small molecule with mechanistic actions on cholinesterase, MAO and multiple neuroprotective pathways (including effects on oxidative stress, microglial activation, and APP processing), classifying this trial as 'disease-targeted small molecule' best fits the provided category definitions. One possible alternate interpretation is 'cognitive enhancer' because cholinesterase inhibition can improve cognition acutely; however the trial goal (delay onset/progression) and cited neuroprotective mechanisms support the disease‑targeted small molecule classification. Sources: phase‑2 clinical trial report and mechanistic review articles. citeturn0search0turn0search2
explanation_agent: Reason: The investigational drug ladostigil (TV‑3326) is a small molecule with multiple mechanistic actions — dual cholinesterase (AChE/ChE) and brain‑selective monoamine oxidase (MAO‑A/B) inhibition plus reported neuroprotective, antioxidant and anti‑inflammatory effects. These span several CADRO domains (neurotransmitter systems, inflammation, oxidative stress, and neuroprotection), so the most specific CADRO assignment is R) Multi‑target. citeturn0search2turn0search1

Act: Key extracted details from the trial description and the literature — drug: ladostigil (TV‑3326); primary molecular actions: cholinesterase inhibition and brain‑selective MAO inhibition; additional reported effects: neuroprotection, antioxidant activity, anti‑inflammatory effects, and modulation of APP processing. The 36‑month phase‑2 MCI study tested low‑dose ladostigil (≈10 mg/day) to delay progression to Alzheimer disease. citeturn0search2turn0search1turn0search6

Reflect: Classification check — while the drug clearly modulates neurotransmitter metabolism (which could map to CADRO D), it also exerts substantive activity on inflammation, oxidative stress and neuroprotective pathways. Because the intervention intentionally targets multiple biological processes relevant to AD pathogenesis rather than a single, narrow target, R) Multi‑target is the best fit. If a single‑mechanism label were required, one might choose D) Neurotransmitter (cholinergic/monoaminergic) modulation, but that would understate the drug's multimodal profile. citeturn0search1turn0search2

- Mechanism summaries and activity (dual AChE and brain‑selective MAO inhibitor; neuroprotective/antioxidant/anti‑inflammatory): MedChemExpress and GLPBio product/descriptions. citeturn0search2turn0search0
- Experimental/mechanistic studies (effects on APP processing, anti‑apoptotic actions): FASEB / Yogev‑Falach et al. (mechanistic study). citeturn0search1
- Clinical trial (36‑month, low‑dose ladostigil in MCI — phase‑2 placebo‑controlled trial; primary outcome progression to AD): PubMed summary of phase‑2 trial. citeturn0search6
